text: Copper/brown in color with a voluminous light tan head. Aromas of herbal hops and candi. Sweet start, with some lightly caramelized fruit and toasted biscuits. Lightly spicy. Finish has some bubble gum and more toasted malt. Quite light in feel. 7/14

Bottle randomly found at a small bottle shop in Atlanta. Odd find... Mahogany pour with a frothy off white head. Aroma was big time bubble gum, dark fruit, caramel, bready malt. Flavors were much the same, super well rounded and smoothed out. Bubble gum, fruity esters, caramel, earthiness. Super smooth mouthfeel with velvety carbonation. Good stuff.

Picked up single 12-oz bottle from Rileys Wine of the World in Madison, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-clear dark amber brown colored brew with a thick off-white head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some excellent lacing. Aroma of golden and caramel malt, maple candied walnuts, a touch of candi sugar and dark pitted fruits. Taste is full bodied with plenty of carbonation. Flavors of dark pitted fruits, Belgian yeast, a hint of candi sugar and raisins. Finish has a sparkly carbonated Belgian ale aftertaste with some dark pitted fruits and a slowly disappearing yeast aftertaste. A solid Belgian dubbel overall.

Bottle Pour - murky, reddish-brown with a medium head that settles quickly into a lasting film. Aroma is candi sugar, hint of dark fruit, bready...relatively strong, bit of a musty note...not bad, but not great. Flavor is decent as well - quite yeasty, generally sweet but with some back-end bitterness. Palate is medium-bodied. Ok, yet far from great offering, though this admittedly isnt one of my favorite styles...

From a trade awhile ago. Pours a muddy brown with a red hue in my Pig Tulip. Robust dubbel style head. Aroma is prunes, plus, raisins, brown sugar, candied walnuts. Taste is dark fruits, walnuts, light brown sugars, toffee, and caramel. Active carb, medium body. Finish is spiced and candied nuts. Overall good stuff.

Supe clear dark ruby red. Smell of cranberry candies. Palate crisp and sparkles. Mostly flavor so of different red fruits, such as cherries cranberries and raspberries. Some brown malts and walnuts as well.
Smells like a dubbel and pennies and shoe leather. Tastes like a very dry dubbel. A bit minerally, especially in the aftertaste. This one was a miss for me.

12 oz. bottle from my wifes aunt in Madison - thanks again, Gretchen! Pours a cloudy amber color with a finger of off-white head that leaves a lasting film. Notes of caramel, boozy bread, toast, leaves, muddled spice, banana, and earth. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and an earthy, malty, sweet, leafy mouthfeel that finishes dry. Showing more age than it actually has, but still a solid dubbel.

12oz bottle, Hazy amber orange color. Thin off-white head. Loose ropes of lace. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Creamy kind of vegetable aroma, caramel, breadiness. Moderate to bigger sweet taste, light bitterness, kind of dry. Not a great dubbel. Seems old and off; not well-integrated.

12 oz. Bottle to round out Willrunforbeers afternoon cellar clean out. Looks like a bottle date of 05/14 stamped on the neck. Dirty brown color, thin lasting head. Aroma is real nice, spiced apples, raisins and figs. The flavor does reflect the aroma with dark fruit being deep and rich without it becoming to sugary sweet. Yeast helps balance the level of malts. Body is appropriate for the style and has a light spice in the finish. Very nicely crafted from this brewer yet again. Fine example of the style.

12oz bottle. Dated 05/14. Pours medium brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, apple, slight vegetal, slight floral. Taste is caramel, apple, slight vegetal. Banana and yeast show towards the finish.
This poured a darker red color with off white head. Aroma of toast, dark fruit and caramel. Flavor similar, somewhat grassy, almost rustic, and well integrated. Nice stuff.

A yeast bomb? Is it possible? Huge nose of yeast with bits of candied fruit and moist leaves come out of the piles of foam. Not as sweet as the candied sugar ingredients suggest. Harsh, musty and boozy on the finish with hints of raisins. According to other sources, this is the second time New Glarus has released a dubbel, and I would think it possible that brewmaster Dan might rework the recipe for 2015 to make this smoother.

Effervescent pour of properly colored deep amber with a full khaki head. Nose is rich fruitiness, raspberry and plum, currant. Smells heavy. Flavor is rich and sweet, heavy malt forward, tang of deep fruit again. Lighter body that one may expect, but drinkable.

Chestnut brown, moderate head, quickly dissipated. Front notes are brown sugar and caramel; spicy comes through later, but still mildly. Sweet fruits and caramel are laid on thick, though not sickly; in that sense it remains well balanced. The body is fine up front but does seem a little undersupported on the back end. Good beer, very easy drinking, to be sure. Bottle.
Bottle. From notes. Banana, clove, some Belgian candi sugar and a hint of citrus.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of AWISLguy. Thanks! Opened 11/2/14. Pours a hazy brown with a large fizzy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of dates, cherries, brown sugar, bread, caramel, spice. The taste is toffee, brown sugar, rye bread, dark fruits, citrus. Medium bodied, mild lingering fruits, highly carbonated, maybe too highly carbonated. Nice dubbel.

12oz bottle in a stemless glass. Pours deep brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of spicy yeast, sweet and caramel malts, notes of dark fruits, and some light hops. Flavor the same. Average texture, lots of carbonation. A decent beer for the style.

Sampled from bottle courtesy of Mike at POC. Rich sugary dark fruit notes, mild alcohol and caramel, toffee, and light oxidation. Dark amber-copper hazy with thin lacing head. Medium-heavy body with medium-high carbonation. Starts and stays sweet with raisin and toffee. Carbonic fizz and light sugar tang. A little hot with dry spicy finish.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 11-5-14. I have been aging this one for a little while, somewhere between six months and a year, Im guessing. Im not going to bother to research exactly when it was released. Mineral, metallic, plastic aroma features a candy sugar scent. Smells like a cheap metal railing. Fresh and yeasty yet simultaneously rusty smell. Overall, a subpar aroma. Pours a dark amber to medium brown with a large amount of long-lasting, golden taupe head that is fluffy. Quite good looking in the glass. Hazy liquid. Light effervescence. Gorgeous and hard to beat appearance, except that it produces only a small amount of lacing. Better lacing would have earned it a 5 for appearance. Spicy, Christmas-y taste features flavors of tobacco, leather, bran muffin, sugary apple, dull metal, and dirt. Low in flavor but not bad. Medium body. Lively, frothy, and soft in the palate. Produces some alcohol heat in the back of the throat. Overall, disappointing. Pretty bad smell and underwhelming flavor and palate effects. It does look good, but its unsophisticated and underdeveloped. New Glarus has produced some really good stuff in its Thumbprint line, but it also has had a surprisingly large number of clunkers. This is one of the clunkers. Dont be fooled by the generous ratings from people who dont have the heart to knock a New Glarus beer; this one is not very good at all.

12 ounce bottle

A special treat carted home from the GTMW weekend, this dubbel represents a typical New Glarus Thumbprint release. Fairly priced with a flavor profile that is likely to hold up for at least a few months, it should find its way into the fridge or cellar of anyone who wants to know why New Glarus continues to be a huge influence in the craft beer movement.

Aroma / Appearance - A rich ruby red base flows with a sticky resistance. Dusty white head adds a nice accent. Underneath waves of nutty caramel, walnuts, and bittersweet chocolate merge with effortless direction from the base malts.

Flavor / Palate - Carbonated Dr Pepper tickles the tongue. A second later a burst of cherries, iced tea leaves, and residual toffee contribute more depth. A vinous texture completes the experience as it winds to a warm full bodied conclusion. A top notch winter warmer may not last that long as I look at my remaining stash of bottles.

Pours to a deep bronze mahogany body with a foamy off-white head. The aroma is yeasty sugary caramel with that rock candi quality and green raisins. Typical to the best Belgium brewers. The flavor is sweet yeasty green raisins with rock sugar. Esters are earthy. The palate is medium bodied and the flavor lingers. Chewy. Creamy. Westmalle still has the best.

Poured from a 12oz bottle. 
I really wanted to like this beer but found it too solventy tasting. I will give it a fair shake and try another six pack. I may have had a tainted batch.

12oz bottle pours a hazy amber with some creamy, off white head. Nose has candy sugar, clove, some raisin, a little banana peel. Flavor is sweet, raisins, dried cherry, a little soap. Lightly sweet finish.
Bottle. Good dubbel. Aroma has some dried fruit and malt. Medium sweet flavor, compared to many of the style, which can be overly sweet. some flavor of unsweetened chocolate and earthy.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, thanks Jeff for holding onto this for me! Hazy dark reddish brown pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of dark fruits, raisin, plum, alcohol soaked fruits, hints of toast, caramel, some slight spice, pretty rich. Taste is a mix of dark fruit, toffee, dark cocoa almost with some toast, spice, yeast, hints of raisin, finishing fairly sweet.

Bottle at home. Pour is hazy brown with a big tan head and good lacing. Banana, clove, light caramel, yeasty, brown sugar, and doughy aroma. Taste is caramelly, yeasty, lightly astringent, some spice, brown sugar, and bread with a semi fruity finish. Medium body with high carb. Not the best Dubbel I have had.

12oz bottle. Cap came off with a pop, no gusher but the light brown but mostly off white head sure filled up the glass before settling down over a hazy orangy mahogany beverage. Some apples with a bit of brown sugar, Belgian yeast, bit bready, some coriander, nutmeg, high carbonation, mild+ body, somewhat sweet, becomes moderately dry but also a bit cloying with somewhat overwhelming spice and yeast on the finish.

Bottle. Pours perfectly into a Westmalle glass with a good thick beige head. Nose is tasty - toasted malt, mild mulling spices and some saaz-like hops. Flavor is simple but pretty good - residual candi sugar sweetness dominates, some banana and clove from the yeast and a bit of caramel malt. Finish is semi-dry with lingering flavors of yeast and hop. Pretty good American take on a difficult style - I agree with other reviewers that cellaring this would help to dry it out a bit and bring more complexity. Good, but this will be great a year from now.

12oz Bottle. Thanks Andy! Strong apple aroma with rose and browned sugars. Apples dominate the flavor, with astringent tannins and lots of alcohol. Im not in love with this. Its got the digestability of the Belgian originals, but the yeast character is too ebullient and flowery. The residual malt flavor is heavily stained with special B and crystal.

> Overcarbonated red apple and soy whoopsie 
[ Bottle ][ 12oz ][ Discount Liquor Milwaukee ][ $2.50 ][ Oerbier Stemware ][ 8.21.14 ]
>> Highly carbonated pour results in a murky umber pour with massive yellow foam that towers out of the glass. Weak retention though and little lacing. Nose is phenolic, cider at first (volatiles). Cleans up to prunes and dates, red oxidized apple slices, and soy. Taste is bubbly up front, overcarbonated, with a seltzer like drained finish. Modest alcohol warmth. Finish is oily and medium bodied. Minerally flavor with mild soy. Not much body or density. Feels like this one might over overattenuated. 
>!< drier, overcarbonated
Dark amber to brown color, tan head. Malt and bread aroma with spice notes. Strong taste all the way. Nice.
Bottle. Deep copper with very large beige head. Aroma, malt, some CO2 burn, and light caramel. Medium body, malt, raisins, medium sweetness, very effervescent, and very metallic/copper finish.
Amber in color, off white head. Banana bread, spice cake, caramel malts, figs and dates. Pretty ok.
not a huge fan of dubbels, but this one is ok. not something i would pick up again.
Pours a hazy dark reddish brown with off-white head. Spice, caramel, toffee, biscuit, and yeast on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with a little sweetness.

Bottle @ home, thanks to TheAlum for sending! Pours a hazy reddish brown appearance with a heavy brown head. Red apple, banana, candy sugar, cooking spices in the nose with some fairly bitter herbal hops. Nice mouth feel. Slightly metallic. Toffee, burnt sugar, white fruits in the flavor. Pretty well balanced. Hint of oxidation. Its decent but maybe should have been drank a bit more fresh.
Bottle from Steves in Madison. Pours a cloudy amber. A good version of the style--lots of malt, dark fruits--cherry and raisin--a nice spicy yeast finish. I like it.

Pours copper colored with a huge tan head mostly lasting. Nose is caramel with some fruitiness. Very creamy with plenty of carbonation on the palate. The taste is of caramel, bread, yeast with some fruit notes. No bitterness. Finishes slightly sweet with carbonation throughout. A fine complex beer. Can be enjoyed alone or with nuts or mild cheeses.
Bottle. Musty, yeasty toffee malt and cherry aroma. Dark amber with large head. Musty cherry and toffee malt flavor. Dry finish. Pretty good - very dry for the style.

12oz bottle purchased back in March when it was first released, pours a clear dark brown with a red hue to it and a really thick egg shelled colored head and lots of lacing, aroma is sweet with lots of candi sugar coming through with some dark fruit mixed in as well, flavor has a lot of dark fruit at first with a kick of spices and caramel in the finish, nice mouthfeel, not a huge fan of this style but seems pretty nice.

On tap at Brat Shop poured into a shaker. Pours clear dark amber with small off-white head. Aroma i small off-white head. Aroma is caramel, low/medium carbonation and good small bubble lacing. Taste is caramel, candy sugar, and hints of alcohol. I prefer many other dubbels.
Bottle thanks to Matt. Pours a cloudy copper with small beige head. The aroma is strong candy sugar, oak, yeast, and raisin. Medium mouthfeel with sweet sugary malt, yeast, and raisin. Good.
Bottle during RBSG 2014. Hazy dark golden brown with off-white head. Aromas of figs, raisins, dark fruit, caramel. Tastes of raisins, caramel, dark fruit. Medium body and dry.

Bottle from Keir, thanks man! Muddy brown pour with lots of off colour velvety white head. Aroma is spices, brown sugar, raisins,figs and fruity esters. Taste is fairly spice driven up front, a bit of raisin with some mild sweetness follows, finish is mildly bitter and fairly dry. Overall, its a bit thin, not my favourite double but not bad.

808s n FartRates review #11
Pours orange with a decent head and lacing on the glass. 

The atom aid fruity with some apple & cherry. A lightly but effectively spicy bouquet is inviting enough. 

The flavor has some brown sugar and cherry. Its spicy with some leafiness and some caramel. 

Its decidedly not my favorite of the series but its an enjoyable beer never the less.

12 oz bottle from Hilltop Brewery (New Glarus, WI). Pours a deep darker copper ruby hue, gentle haziness with darker middle. Lively carbonation atop shows cakey light brown head. Firmer layer dies to a decent film eventually, cakey layer laces well enough. Aromas are firmer red fruit, touches of prune and plum meet black cherry, a bit of toffee and toast. Carmelized and biscuity malts, some sweeter touches of red currant, a gentle yeastiness and Belgian spice. Fruity and sweeter than expected with some Belgian candi sugar. Initial is well carbonated, medium bodied with red fruit, plum and some dried fruit. Touches of currant, cherry and caramel malts. Biscuits, some estery fruits and toffee. Well carbonated and a bit fuzzy, gentle Belgian yeast and spiciness, lighter body (though still sweet) from all these effects. A bit of banana, more toast and bready/carmelized malt elements give some more expected Dubbel elements. Lingering red fruit, not into the cough syrup realm but it hovers close by. A lot of red/stone/dark fruit elements really come through on this thing. Coupled with that well carbonated body, a bit of spiciness, toast, gentle carmelized candi sugar finish. Faint black olive lingers at times as well back there and on the palate. This is ok, considerably different than expected but still fairly solid. Gorgeous pour, a touch more body and depth, apple and banana flashes and estery life at times after we get much further in. Perhaps a bit overattenuated? Or maybe Im just used to the plethora of under attenuated Dubbels made here by US Brewers? Something is different, the nose seems a bit dead as well.
Bottle shared at RBSG. Thanks phaleslu! Pours an amber color with white head. Candi sugar, malty, spicy aromas. Malty, metallic, spicy flavors. A little disappointing.

Bottle @ Presidential Suite. Thanks, Peter. Light brown/dark amber pour with a khaki head. Nose is rather metallic. Dark fruit such as raisins and black cherry. A touch of banana and some caramel malt. As with the aroma, tons of metal on the tongue. Kind of bitter. Tinny. Some caramel, chocolate, and a touch of fruit...mostly banana and raisin.

Shared at RBSG 2014 in the Presidential Suite. Thanks Peter! Strong candi sugar in the nose with toffee and something that reminds me of bacon. Fairly light brown in color with a large head. Taste is slightly metallic and blood-like; minerally. I think theres a yeast/water clash or something going on here that really masks the base characteristics of the style, unfortunately.

Fruity candy sweet aroma with just a hint of sour in the background. Pours cloudy caramel amber with a thick foamy light tan head that fades fairly quickly leaving a small amount of lacing. Caramel, fruit (plum, cherry) slightly earthy, slightly yeasty, smooth with a dry finish. Very nice.
Dark brown. Smells of spices. Tastes like rock candy with a little cinnamon at the end. Pretty dynamic. Thanks Erin.

Poured from bottle in tulip glass. Golden brown hue. Thick, high retention head. Pleasant, not overwhelming scent. Complex-ish woody, spicy flavor, gets better as it sits in the glass. Pretty solid overall, nice beer.

12oz bottle... Thanks, Brock. Aroma is yeasty. Appearance is a dark bronze with a fluffy, tan head. Taste is Belgian yeast with a rAw medium malt flavor. Palate is different because I the yeast. Overall, a decent beer. I think it may be better a littler warmer and during the fall.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pour is reddish/amber with a medium white head. Aroma is of light caramel, dried fruit, belgian candi sugar, and spice. Flavor is similar but a bit more on the sweet side. Spice on the finish.

Light ruby - moderate haze - cream, thick lace - nose of toffee, treacle, raisin,date, rye bread, all spice, cardamom - nice, full, creamy texture - full body - rich malt sweetness, tempered by moderate tartness and dry, earthy, dusty yeast character - flavors of date, dark.bread, nutmeg - peppery phenolics and moderate esters - finish is earthy (basement), with lingering spiciness, pepper, baked apples - excellent dubbel, almost as good as the anniversary ale.

Bottle: pour is murky mahogany with a two finger, fine bubbled khaki head into this glass. Retention is modest , with light lacing in this glass. The nose is brown and candied sugars, and a strong fruit presence. The flavor profile shares some character with the spiced ale I just had. Perhaps theres a similar hop bill. Anyway, this one is fruit ester, charred oak, toffee, moving to candied sugar with bittering hops rounding it out. This is not what I want from the style. At all. Its lacking a certain round softness, and belgian character that I expect out if a great dubbel
From a bottle poured in a tulip. Pours rusty brown. Flavor is rich and spicy with medium body and light bitterness and a clean finish. Solid dubbel, but perhaps a little too far on the light side.

12 ounce bottle poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a dark amber with a big beige head of foam with great retention. The aroma has a lot of dark fruits. I get a lot of raisin and fig influence and some burnt caramel. The taste is pretty sweet, but theres a hint at some spices as well. Airy mouthfeel. I wish that had a little thicker of a mouthfeel. Moderate to high carbonation.

Bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a lasting amber head. Aromas of spice, toffee, dried fruit, banana and light yeast. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of toffee, yeast, spice and light fruitiness with a smooth lingering spiced toffee finish.

Bottle. Clear amber pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of banana, sweet caramel and clove. Sweet caramel flavor with toffee character and slight banana before a drying finish. Different than a lot of dubbels due to dominant sweet caramel character, which is likely due to the long boil. Well done.
Bottle. Malty aroma with Belgian aspects. Dark hazy brown body. Excellent Belgian dubbel flavor.

[Bottle] Deep brown in color with a pillow of light brown head on top. Nose is of alcohol, spices, fig, plum and Belgian yeast. Caramel, dark fruits, vanilla, fruitcake and cinnamon/spice all make an appearance in the flavor. Lingering alcohol warmth. The flavors came together pretty well. Fine carbonation and nice lacing. Velvety mouthfeel. I saved a few bottles of this and I suspect it will taste even better in a year or so.
Decent Dubbel - malty and true to the style from across the ocean. Crisp and clean finish.

Pours a dark caramel color. Highly carbonated with a thick off-white head. Aroma is cloves with hints of oranges and apricots. Its sweet but not cloyingly so. Caramel, brown sugar, and candied fruit are all present but the hops presence is just strong enough to balance all the sweetness. The finish is not at all bitter but just dry enough to cut through the malt. All in all a very tasty strong ale.

Pours an amber color with medium off-white head. Aroma is caramel, dried dark fruits, candied sugar. Taste is much the same. Good balance of maltiness. That being said, Ive never been a huge fan of this style. Too sweet.

12oz bottle 5/11/14 (Woodmans-Waukesha)-45° in Trappist Glass-Pours brown with a small tan head. Aroma of yeast, dried fruits, caramel, and malt. Taste of the same with some spices coming in on the back end. This full bodied brew is well balanced and goes down smooth. Great brew.

Bottle. Pours an overcarbonated soda pop-like head. Rich ruby red brown in color. Aroma is tart cherry and spice cake. First impression on the taste falls a bit short. Musty chocolate notes at first, then a tangy, sour finish. Carbonation is dialed up pretty high. Laid the other 3 down, hope this will mellow with age.

Bottle from Rays in Tosa. Pours a brownish tan with an off-white head. Some streaks of lace. Aroma has sweet fruits, belgian esters & spices and candied sugars. Light and pleasant. Taste is of sweet fruits - with some banana and some cherry/other stone fruits - and spicy belgian yeast. Solid and tasty with some complexity. Light to medium bodied and tangy. Finishes sweet and spicy, with some effervescence. Solid, true-to-style effort. Will be interesting to age.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a thick khaki head that coats the glass. Aroma of caramel, toffee, belgian esters and dark fruits. Flavor is sweet and fruity. Flavor has medium sweetness, very mild balancing bitterness. Some earthiness towards the finish. Smooth, superior mouthfeel. In fact, this is the closest to a Trappist mouthfeel Ive ever had in an American beer. This is a stunning take on a style that doesnt get much attention in the craft beer scene nowadays.

12oz bottle: pours a transparent deep copper with a clingy-lacing froth of light beige head. Has a sweet toasty dark caramel malty nose with some biscuity notes and a touch of anise. Starts with good fullness and effervescent carbonation with bready sweetness, some banana esters, and dark fruits before a drier toasted finish. Pretty true to style and well-balanced.

Bottle thanks to Jstax ! Pours rusty brown color with a two finger eggshell foam. Lots of mild warming spice on the nose, caramel malt, bready, burnt sugar. Palate follows with a soft fuzzy mouthfeel. Layers of date fruit, french toast, vanilla, molasses and prune. Pretty good representation of style.

Deep, clear red body and a thick tan head. Grains, some grassiness, maybe even a hint of maybe mushroom. Predominantly sour, some bitterness. Incredibly dry palate, medium body, quite effervescent between its acidity and carbonation. Quite nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown red with a thick v thick head from bottle. Aroma is mild alcohol and grapes, like a wine, red wine. Theres a hair in it. Wtf? Flavor is mild and a little sour.

Purchased at Woodmans in Kenosha, WI; enjoyed at home prior to watching Blackhawks playoff hockey, cautiously nervous. Appearance is a rich mahogany-esque amber with a moderate off white head that laces to the glass. Looks classy. Aroma of Belgian candi sugar, light spice, yeast. Taste is rich and syrupy, sweet, moderate caramel notes, its good but not my fav from this great brewery.

Bottle, bonused by Bacterial -- thanks! Pours brown with ruby highlights. Aroma hits me first with an almost artificial cherry -- like cherry wrapped in plastic thats begun to melt. Caramel, toffee, and then the fruit again. Hard for me to get past that. Medium body, sweet and syrupy. Sticky. Overall: not my favorite from them, but I still maintain my standing order to try anything these folks brew. This also reminds me I should revisit some of the dubbels I enjoyed in the days before I was rating, though.
Bottle. pours clear reddish hazel, large creamy beige head, dissipates slowly, nice lacing. Aroma is, nutty, malty, caramel. Medium sweet, miNimal bitterness. Rich and creamy, quite tasty.

Hazy brownish color, like good cider. Good amount of tan head. Aroma of fruit, spice, and some booze. Taste is very much a Belgian beer. Great yeast flavor, caramel, fruit, raisins, some molasses. Full bodied, with a sticky and fizzy finish. Another great beer from New Glarus.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle thanks to Neal pours a dark copper orange with a large off white head. Caramel and bready taste. As it warms vanilla and clove flavors come out.

Bottled. Poured slightly cloudy medium orange with a tall, fluffy beige head. The aroma picked up biscuity and raisin notes upfront, with accents of vanilla, cloves, and charred oak.. came across a touch airy, but otherwise quite nice. The flavor found a heavier dose of raisin and molasses at the core, with warm spices, oak, and a bit of vinous character around.. finished spicy and a touch heavy. Medium-bodied with fairly high carbonation on the palate.. this came together well, and I think a bit of time will make it even better.

Bottle thanks to joshmcg000. Hazy, dark copper tinted brown pour with a tall, fluffy beige head that has great retention and leaves very nice lacing. Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit, Candi Sugar, tree fruit, sweet cherries, fruity floral notes, a little banana bread, a touch of lemon curd and nice, deep toasty pastry notes. Flavor is chocolate, dark toast, roast, wine soaked dark fruit, light nutty notes, roasted stone fruit, spice, banana, bubble gum, dates, caramel then some floral notes, crusty bread, toffee and spice to the finish. Medium body, creamy to syrupy feel, with a medium, blanketing carbonation and off dry finish. Really good stuff, one of the better Dubbels I have had. It really opens up around cellar temp, which is probably how it should be drank.

Pours a deep amber with a finger of frothy head. Aroma is intensely malty with notes of brown sugar, stone fruit, and spicy yeast. Taste follows quite well with a medium body, an oily finish and overall sweet taste. As it warmed I enjoyed it more.

Pours hazy to dark tan very nice looking. Aroma is heavy Belgian yeast. Very heavy yeast flavor up front, little bit of nice spice. It has very nice active carbonation that fits it well, little bit of sweetness to. Sharp hoppy bitterness on the backend. Pretty good

The color is an opaque brown with a large light tan head, which is appealing, but the aroma smells stale bread, which isnt appetizing. The taste is mildly sour, slightly sweet, and a touch umami, and the palate fuses a medium body, average carbonation, thick texture, and a sour finish.

Murky brown-orange pour. Nose is brown sugar, Belgian yeast, candy, light apple, and faint banana. Flavor is initially Belgian candy and cherry that finishes quickly to burnt biscuit and toasted malt. Lingering burnt biscuit and faint roasted malt. Fairly dry and highly carbonated. Initial impression was that this was a bit choppy, but as it warmed, so did I to the overall picture. Still, certainly could use some age, mellowing of components
355ml bottle. Brown pour, spices and fruits in the flavor, decently dry, very ncie.
Deep amber with an off white head. Nose is yeast, dried fruits, light spice, and bread. Easy palate, heavy yeast, dried fruits, caramel, with a sweet finish.

12oz bottle. Rating #10...its official. Murky burgundy-amber body. Creamy off-white/beige head. At first I was disappointed with this beer, because it didnt taste like your run of the mill Dubbel. It is lighter is some respects, leans into the amber malt a little. Spicy intense yeast tones. The more I sip at it though, I have to give it props. This has classic Belgian nuances, complexities. The luscious champagne mouthfeel is there. Like a Trappist interpretation of a Dubbel, going for greatness, not content to make a standard offering. Pretty solid beer.

Aroma: toasty, malty, some raisin and fig, slight spiciness.
Appearance: reddish brown pour, thick khaki head with good retention, leaves some thin lacing.
Taste: caramel, toast, dark fruit (plum and fig), toffee, some spice, low bitterness.
Palate: medium body, medium-high carbonation.
Overall: decent brew, nice toffee and caramel notes.

Bottle - Murky ruby-brown pour with a foamy light tan head. Nose is plasticy--thats the dominant aspect, with plum, raisin, a bit of bready yeast, and even some light spicing. Taste has the same plasticy note, though not as strong, with yeasty bread, and lightly spiced plum. A bit of boozy sharpness on the finish, but not much. Its not bold and luscious, but as with the Chocolate Abbey NG made previously, I expect this one could use 3-6 months in the cellar to come together better. As it stands its fairly tasty, but the smell and the disjointed nature of the taste mean its more middling than magnificent.

This pours a cloudy, burnt amber color with a slight off-white head. The aroma is mildly sweet with malts and yeast. The taste is quite strong with malt and yeast. There is a full volume with a decent amount of carbonation. It finishes with a bit of a spice after taste and lingering yeast. A very interesting brew from New Glarus.

(bottle) Pours a semi-hazy brown color with an off-white head that quickly settles to a medium height. Scent is pretty subtle post-pour, with a subtly dominant aroma of freshly cut plum carrying the torch. There is also some dessicated fruit components flitting in on the fringes of the sniff. Perhaps some dried apple slices and the case could be made for cherries, although it may be flimsy. Subtle hint of Vics vapo-rub. Odd. More normal scents of bread and toffee show up as well.  Further warming reveals some black cardamom. The flavor, as with most New Glarus forays into Belgian territory, falls flat, and the rounded breadiness of the yeast seen in prime Belgian examples is notably absent here. In its place is a slightly tart and sharp aspect to the finish which is a bit jarring for the style. There are some spicy aspects to this such as cinnamon (warming, not stinging) and perhaps clove. Again, the dried apple and plum arrive along with some caramel. As Ive tasted in the past, and currently am tasting here, NGs attempts at Belgian styles generally fall flat. This is a middling rendition of what can be an intriguing style.

12oz bottle to snifter. Beautiful deep ruby red with thick creamy off white head. Candi sugar, yeast, and dark fruits. Smooth carbonation with just a little bite. Everything I like about dubbels but Im getting a little bit of odd plasticy aroma and Im usually not very sensitive to aroma. Otherwise its spectacular.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2014 Pours an attractive dark ruby reddish, light brownish amber. Medium, creamy light tan head, fairly lasting with lacing. Belgian yeast, spicy, fruity, banana, little dark fruit, brown sugar, caramel. Modest sweetness. Finishes dry and doughy with a touch a sweetness and spice. Big medium body, very soft, creamy. Alcohol is well hidden. Very smooth, rounded, balanced. Oozes quality all around. For a fault, if anything maybe its a bit too subtle and understated, if you can even consider that a fault. A dangerously drinkable, approachable dubbel.
Taste is fairly smooth, malty, dried fruit (raisin), dark fruit, smooth, robust. Aroma is very similar. Creamy malt, some dark fruit. Very smooth, hard to pick out too many particular flavors.

12oz bottle from Downer Wine and Spirits. Sexy new packaging for the Thumbprint Series. Pours a clear, brown color with a tan head. Aroma is brown sugar, some spicy yeast, a little booze. Medium on the palate with soft, creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, caramel, brown sugar, some dark fruit, raisin, a little alcohol heat, with a sweet, fruity finish. His got much better as it warmed up. Id recommend 50F or so.

Hazy Red-Brown with a thin khaki head, no lacing and moderate carbonation. Aroma of brown sugar, dark fruit notes, caramel and belgian yeast. Tastes of belgian yeast, caramel, spice, brown sugar and licorice. Light body and moderate carbonation allows for some of the flavors to flow out. Very good!
